title: Science & Health
content: A young Albertosaurus knows she can't take down a giant alone but she can guide her prey to the matriarch. Florida is pushing to end vaccine mandates as RFK Jr, an immunisation sceptic, remakes US vaccine policy. Electrolyte-packed drinks are said to optimise health and hydration. But do we really need them? Emerging evidence suggests the bacteria living in your gut and mouth influence how you sleep at night. Scientists want to use them to help you rest better. Western medicine views hearing disembodied voices as a symptom of psychosis. But that's not the case everywhere. Most of us know going to bed on a full stomach can affect our sleep. Changing what we eat and the time of day we eat certain foods can help us sleep better. We emit a barrage of whiffy chemicals through our pores and in our breath. Some are a sign that we might be getting ill – and could be used to diagnose diseases up to years in advance. Occasionally the food we eat can interfere with the way drugs are supposed to work. Now scientists are trying to harness these effects to boost the efficacy of treatments. Climate change is contributing to the global rise of Lyme disease. But many physicians are struggling to recognise its symptoms. The number of Japanese centenarians rose to 99,763 in September, with women making up 88% of the total. Fussy eating is very common. A child and baby nutritionist shares her tips on how to manage it. Denmark's survival rates record for certain cancers were poor compared to some other wealthy countries. Then it came up with a bold plan Its decision comes as the industry says there is a lack of government investment and as the US pressures firms to invest there. The team developing advanced flight safety aids in a small South African suburb. Google DeepDream explores how artificial intelligence can produce dream-like art. Artificial intelligence-powered speech synthesisers can now hold eerily realistic spoken conversations and clone the voices of others. Can we tell them apart from the human voice? Artificial intelligence is being used to generate paintings, images and even sculptures, with some selling for thousands of dollars. Do we need to reframe our definition of art? title: Music
content: From pop queens to rap duos, and rave-loving singers to hardcore rockers, we pick our favourite music of the year for you to listen to now. Many towns and cities along the Blues Trail have planned festivals, exhibitions and live music to mark what would have been BB King's 100th birthday. With new album Man's Best Friend, Sabrina Carpenter has sparked controversy that is reminiscent of the outrage over Madonna. Thirty years on, has anything changed for female pop stars? From FKA Twigs to Addison Rae, many of today's hottest pop stars are taking inspiration from Madonna's swirling 1998 masterpiece. What is it that has made the album such a touchstone? Alfred Hitchcock's grisly horror might not have become a classic without composer Bernard Herrmann's disturbing score. The most iconic stars of the 1970s flocked to Record Plant Studios. A new book offers a glimpse inside – and argues that The Eagles' time there inspired the US band's most famous song. The musician explains a heavy moment thinking about the lyrics of a song from his forthcoming album. A wax cylinder containing the oldest recorded country song was discovered in Pennsylvania. Jennifer Lopez explains why she cancelled her tour, and is surprised by a fan in the studio. 75-year-old Bruce Springsteen explains why he has no plans to stop touring. Why certain music can trigger a surprisingly physiological reaction. We discover the power of music on our memories by meeting a care home resident with dementia. We explore where our musical creativity comes from, and what happens to our brains when we improvise. As we grow, how do we connect to music and can it help us to heal? Why do we move to a rhythm, are we actually born to be musical, and how does music really shape who we are? Almost six months ago, members of the rock band Antytila joined the Ukrainian army. title: Art & Design
content: From praying monks and diving swimmers to meteor showers and the tomb of Pope Francis, these are 12 of the most eye-catching and memorable images of the year so far. A listening device hidden in an artwork in 1945 was undetected by US security for seven years – and it's not the only example of art having been manipulated for subterfuge. Georges Seurat's once-mocked painting Bathers at Asnières is both an "exquisite distillation of the very essence of summer" and "a modern wonder in the art of seeing". After a forgotten WW2 propaganda poster was discovered in 2000, it found an astounding new resonance in 21st-Century Britain. title: Style
content: Today's youth are harking back to the messy hipster aesthetic of the late 2000s and early 2010s – and at the heart of that was French designer and queen of cool Isabel Marant. title: Arts in Motion
content: In a pioneering new collaboration, the BBC, in partnership with Rolex, will use its unparalleled reach to bring the best arts and culture to audiences worldwide. Rolex's long-standing commitment to the arts, through its Perpetual Arts Initiative, is coupled with the BBC's storytelling heritage to support and promote artistic excellence and the transmission of artistic knowledge. This is Arts in Motion, a long-term joint project to enable and highlight creative ambition on a global scale. Yuja Wang is one of the world’s most exciting classical pianists. She reveals her process and how Chopin changed her life. SeokJong Baek, a celebrated tenor with the Royal Ballet and Opera, sings Nessun Dorma by Puccini. What if a single note could change a life? title: Destinations
content: From Spain to South Africa, nations are investing big in sports infrastructure to attract the growing wave of travelling fans.
